required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Impact of the Covid-19 on RSV Epidemic
clinical_study.official_title: Impact of the Covid-19 Pandemic on the Epidemiology of Respiratory Syncytial Virus

brief_summary.textblock: The magnitude of seasonal RSV epidemics brings each year new logistical challenges for the hospitalization of young infants with bronchiolitis that overwhelm hospital capacities and lead to specific winter plans with deprogramming and mobilization of human and logistical resources. The Covid-19 pandemic has changed the way winter epidemics are presented. For example, the seasonal RSV epidemic was shifted by several months in Lyon, with an impression of a lower incidence of hospitalized cases, with a population of older children and with fewer signs of clinical severity. This is largely attributable to the widespread use of barrier gestures and social distancing measures, known as "non-pharmacological interventions" or NPI. Given the magnitude of the reduction of the RSV epidemic, it is legitimate to analyze the benefits of NPIs to draw lessons for maintaining preventive measures around RSV-vulnerable populations; moreover, new preventive pharmacological interventions are soon to be marketed, whether they are particularly refined and long half-life anti-RSV monoclonal antibodies, RSV vaccines for mothers or for newborns and infants. In this perspective, it is crucial to properly define the populations at risk of severe disease to establish a legitimate hierarchy in the implementation of different preventive strategies. The study of the RSV epidemic is a high potential model because of the convergence of epidemiological, virological, and pharmacological knowledge. However, the study of the impact of the pandemic on the epidemiology of rhinovirus also seems promising because, for reasons unknown to date, it seems that the pandemic did not have the same reducing impact on the rhinovirus epidemic; in the latter case, the interest is to confirm the resistance of this virus and to look for more fundamental explanations, for example, on viral interactions.

primary_outcome.measure: Reduction of the number of children hospitalized for a RSV-infection during pre and post-Covid-19 pandemic RSV-winter-epidemic.
primary_outcome.time_frame: 2019-2020-winter-epidemic and 2020-2021-winter-epidemic are assessed during June and July, 2021.

arm_group.description: Children hospitalized in the Pediatric Department of the Hôpital Femme Mère Enfant, Lyon, France with a RT-PCR positive for RSV during the 2019-2020 winter epidemic
Children hospitalized in the Pediatric Department of the Hôpital Femme Mère Enfant, Lyon, France with a RT-PCR positive for RSV during the 2020-2021 winter epidemic

intervention.description: To review of medical records to describe diagnosis and severity of the disease.
To compare pre and post Covid-19 epidemics in terms of numbers of admissions, and proportion of severe disease.

study_pop.textblock: Child hospitalized at Hôpital Femme Mère Enfant, Lyon, France with viral respiratory infection.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- • Child hospitalized at Hôpital Femme Mère Enfant, Lyon, France
- PCR positive à VRS
Exclusion Criteria:
- • Parent's refusal to participate

facility.name: Groupement Hospitalier EST - Hospices Civils de Lyon
